header.type: HUMAN RIGHTS VIOLATIONS, SUBMISSIONS QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS

testimony: Thank you, Mr Chairman, I would like you, Mam, to take an oath.  Nondithini Irene Nosakele Kiva, please stand up.

Thank you.  I will lead her with questions, Mr Chairperson.  We have your story here in front of us.  I would like you to give us a picture of what was happening in Adelaide during this time when Andile was murdered.

It was on a Saturday, it was on a Saturday.  Andile went to visit his friends in Dubane.  They were chased away by the soldiers.  They found him, they assaulted him with rifle butts.  The took him to the police station.  When they arrived there they assaulted him.  In the morning they took him to the hospital.
How old was Andile at the time?  Was he at school or was he not at school?
He was about 19 years old.  He was not at school, he was working.
Was he a member of any organisation in Adelaide?
I think so, but I am not sure.
What was the reason for his assault?
It was a time when the police found you in the streets, they would assault you even if you did not do anything.
You are saying that the police were beating everybody in the street?
Yes, people were assaulted that year.
The police you mentioned here, Mbulelo Tom, you said that Mbulelo Tom said your dog is dead.  Do you know him?
No, he was not born in Adelaide.
When he said that your dog is dead, what was the reason for him to say this?  Please keep quiet at the door.
He was in a Hippo and he told me that Witbooi is dead.  When I tried to cry he said, why do you cry, your dog is dead.
Did they, was there any conflict between him and your son before?
No, there was no charge laid against him.
Did you lay a charge against him?
Why did you not lay a charge against him?
I think we were not aware.
As you are here today in this Commission, what would you like the Commission to do for you?

As Andile was a breadwinner, he was helping his mother to support the children, but my mother died and she
left the children alone.
These children are Andile's sister.  Nobody is supporting them and nobody is paying for their education.
Would like us to help them?
The other one has passed standard ten and the other one is doing standard six.
Do you have anything else you want to add?
No, there is nothing.  They are homeless if the Commission can help them to get a place to stay.
Thank you.  Thank you Mr Chairperson, I hand over to you.
Thank you Mr Chairperson.  You said that you did not lay a charge against him?
Were you afraid or what was the reason?
Yes, we were afraid, because at that time it was difficult to go to the police to lay a charge.
Were the police protecting people in the community?
No, the people were not protected.
In other words you mean that you were scared of the police?
Yes, we were scared of the police in the community.  You would not go to the police station to ask the whereabouts of your family member, they would beat you up.
Thank you, Mam.  Thank you Mr Chairperson.
Mrs Nosakele, what is your relationship between yourself and Andile?
He passed away when they were still young.
In other words, Andile was your responsibility?
When you were giving your testimony, if I heard you correctly, you said this incident happened by the, the police were in a Hippo.  Where was this Hippo?
What happened to, what do you think happened to Andile?
I am not sure, because they were chased away by the police and they ran away, but they managed to find Andile.
Everybody who was with Andile was chased away?
Were these members of an organisation?
You said that this Hippo got an accident.  Was it in Dubane location?
Are there any other questions?  June Crichton.
Ma Kiva, can you hear me?  Can you hear me?  There is just one question I want to ask you.  There was a witness to this attack by the name of Zibangele.  Who is he?
Yes, there was a witness by the name of Zibangele.
And so, he saw the whole incident.
No, but, because he ran away, he did not see.
But was it him that came to tell you about it?
Yes, he came to me saying that they were chased away by the Hippo.
Alright, thank you very much.  Thank you, Mr Chair.

Mrs Nosakele, we thank you for coming to this Commission.  It is very painful to see that your cousin was killed like a dog.  As you have already said that Tom said that the dog is dead.  It is very painful that after he was murdered there was no court case.  You did not get any compensation as a family.  What Tom said that Andile is dead, it is very painful.  We thank you for coming here on behalf of your sister to tell the story to the Commission in order to show that Andile was not a dog, he was a human-being.  We, as the Commission, we will investigate about this matter.  We will make sure that the death of Andile will not be like the death of an animal.  We will try to ask Tom questions if he is still alive in order to know what was happening at that time.  Maybe Tom will know that the death of a person is very painful, it is not like the death of a dog.  We thank you very much.  We will come back to you to get some clarity on certain issues.  Thank you.
